user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of add_new_user_entry:
```c
static int
add_new_user_entry (const char *const username,
                    const char *const password,
                    const char *const realm,
                    int allow_area_1,
                    int allow_area_2)
{
  struct UserEntry *entry;
  enum MHD_Result res;

  if ((sizeof(user_ids) / sizeof(user_ids[0])) <= user_ids_used)
    return 0; /* No more space to add new entry */

  entry = user_ids + user_ids_used;

  entry->username = username;
  entry->realm = realm;

  res = MHD_YES;

  if (MHD_NO != res)
    res = MHD_digest_auth_calc_userhash (MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_MD5,
                                         username,
                                         realm,
                                         entry->userhash_md5,
                                         sizeof(entry->userhash_md5));
  if (MHD_NO != res)
    res = MHD_digest_auth_calc_userdigest (MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_MD5,
                                           username,
                                           realm,
                                           password,
                                           entry->userdigest_md5,
                                           sizeof(entry->userdigest_md5));

  if (MHD_NO != res)
    res = MHD_digest_auth_calc_userhash (MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA256,
                                         username,
                                         realm,
                                         entry->userhash_sha256,
                                         sizeof(entry->userhash_sha256));
  if (MHD_NO != res)
    res = MHD_digest_auth_calc_userdigest (MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA256,
                                           username,
                                           realm,
                                           password,
                                           entry->userdigest_sha256,
                                           sizeof(entry->userdigest_sha256));

  if (MHD_NO != res)
    res = MHD_digest_auth_calc_userhash (MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA512_256,
                                         username,
                                         realm,
                                         entry->userhash_sha512_256,
                                         sizeof(entry->userhash_sha512_256));
  if (MHD_NO != res)
    res =
      MHD_digest_auth_calc_userdigest (MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA512_256,
                                       username,
                                       realm,
                                       password,
                                       entry->userdigest_sha512_256,
                                       sizeof(entry->userdigest_sha512_256));

  if (MHD_NO == res)
    return 0; /* Failure exit point */

  entry->allow_area_1 = allow_area_1;
  entry->allow_area_2 = allow_area_2;

  user_ids_used++;

  return ! 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
res = MHD_digest_auth_calc_userdigest (MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA256,
                                           username,
                                           realm,
                                           password,
                                           entry->userdigest_sha256,
                                           sizeof(entry->userdigest_sha256));
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation in this fragment as written: the local pointer parameter password is declared as const char *const and is passed through — that complies with Rule 8.13. A violation would occur only if the callee’s prototype declares the corresponding parameter as a non-const pointer (e.g. char *password). In that case the const qualifier would be discarded when passing password and the callee’s declaration should be changed to take a const-qualified pointer (const char *), or an explicit cast used (the latter is not recommended).
